awd_titl_txt: IGE: Enhancing imaginative and collaborative STEM capacity through creative inquiry
awd_abstract_narration:
Advanced scientific and technical training is insufficient to position the leaders of tomorrow to solve the complex problems we face. They must also be able to think creatively, to collaborate across disciplines, and to work with people with different perspectives, knowledge, and values. There is compelling evidence that creativity training can stimulate both scientific creativity and interdisciplinary collaboration, but to date, little attention has been given to creativity training in STEM graduate education. This National Science Foundation Innovations of Graduate Education (IGE) award to the University of Georgia will bring a diverse group of graduate students together from STEM and arts disciplines to address issues in the local watershed using creativity-based training methods from the arts. This project will investigate the impact of targeted creativity training on the ability of STEM students to frame problems in new ways and help diverse teams solve complex problems. If successful, widespread adoption of these methods will contribute to equipping STEM graduates across the country with communication and collaboration skills and ultimately increase creative and innovative solutions to complex global environmental challenges.

Over each of five semesters, this project will recruit a cohort of ten students in the early stages of graduate study, five from STEM disciplines who self-identify as interested in environmental science, and five from arts disciplines. Cohorts will meet for six workshops facilitated by two faculty members from STEM and arts disciplines. Workshops are designed to build core creative competencies and develop skills for collaborative interdisciplinary practice. Students will gain practical experience sharing disciplinary viewpoints, creating analogies from scientific concepts, and developing collaborative frameworks for complex problem solving. The final workshop will result in a set of proposed solutions to a local watershed problem, collaboratively identified by students and stakeholders. Complementary quantitative and qualitative methods will be used to examine students' abilities to shift thinking (increase "cognitive flexibility"), generate novel ideas, and effectively communicate and collaborate with one another. This project seeks to fundamentally enhance how STEM students are educated by engaging them in creative processes related to their research topics. Successful elements will be incorporated into a scalable training model that will be widely disseminated and available for adoption at other institutions.

The Innovations in Graduate Education (IGE) program is focused on research in graduate education. The goals of IGE are to pilot, test and validate innovative approaches to graduate education and to generate the knowledge required to move these approaches into the broader community.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
To solve today's most complex challenges, scientists need more than just technical expertise. They must also think creatively and work effectively with people from different backgrounds. Research shows that creativity training can boost scientific innovation and teamwork, yet such training is rarely included in STEM graduate education. The Creativity and Collaboration in STEM project at the University of Georgia (UGA), explored how creativity-based training from the arts can help STEM graduate students improve their problem-solving and collaboration skills. The program brought together graduate students from STEM, arts, and other disciplines for a series of workshops designed to strengthen creative thinking and interdisciplinary teamwork

Key Findings

First, participants unanimously reported that the program was engaging and valuable, for both their professional and personal development. Program evaluators reported that there were four components of the program that created effective learning conditions: 1) activities were open ended and exploratory, 2) activities were fun, but challenging, 3) the environment created by instructors was low-pressure and supportive, and 4) activities were designed to push participants beyond their comfort zones, but in a safe environment. Quantitative analyses showed a modest increase in cognitive flexibility (a measure of creativity) before and after the program. Qualitative analyses indicated that participants increasingly recognized the benefits of working with peers from different disciplines throughout the program, regularly commenting about how the outcomes of various activities that integrated multiple perspectives.

Intellectual Merit

This study provides valuable insights into how graduate education can better prepare students for interdisciplinary problem-solving. Key contributions include:

  • Development of curriculum materials for workshops in Creativity and Collaboration featuring arts-based, STEM-friendly activities.
  • Among 38 participating graduate students, all reported increased imaginative and collaborative abilities, personal observations that were also supported by quantitative and qualitative assessment.
  • Multiple research papers advancing our knowledge of arts-STEM training and collaboration are published or in preparation; results were presented at major conferences; and curriculum will be shared broadly via the web and through partner networks.

Broader Impacts

  • The curriculum has been integrated into other courses, benefiting over 300 students at UGA beyond the 38 participants in the study.
  • The project team is creating an online resource to share the curriculum with graduate educators nationwide.
  • Project leaders have been invited to share results and experiences in a variety of venues, including faculty training seminars, symposia, and spin-off workshops.

Conclusion

This project demonstrated that integrating creativity and collaboration training into STEM graduate education can help future scientists tackle real-world challenges more effectively by enhancing individual motivation and capacity to collaborate and innovate. The project team aims to expand the program's reach, publish research findings, and continue working with universities to enhance graduate education nationwide.
